arguments.claim: Case falls in third class; gift certain by daughters' selection, not void u/s 89

anchor.surface_text: void for uncertainty within the meaning of s. 89, for it can be made certain by the selection of the daughters and is not so uncertain that it is impossible

holdings.text: The provision of s. 89 of the Indian Succession Act applies only to those cases where a will is so indefinite that it is not possible to give any definite intention to it at all.

anchor.surface_text: Now the provision of s. 89 applies only to those cases where a will is so indefinite that it is not possible to give any definite intention to it at all. The illustration to that section shows that it applies only where it is impossible to ascertain the intention of the testator from the words used in the will.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes total indefiniteness (impossible to ascertain intention) from partial uncertainty resolvable by selection; illustration confirms extreme cases only.

holdings.text: In appropriate cases the English rule of benevolent construction that the testator intended the legatee to select should be applied in India also and the decision in Narayanasami Gramani's case is correct.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us therefore that where it is not possible to say on the construction of a will that the testator himself indicated the selection or appointed a third person to make the selection but still intended to make a gift which could be made certain by selection made by the legatee, the English rule of construction that in such cases the testator intended the legatee to select should be applied in India also and the decision in Narayanasami Gramanis case 1 is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule is common sense to effectuate clear intention avoiding litigation; applies where uncertainty partial and resolvable by legatee choice; affirms prior Indian precedent; distinguishes greater uncertainty under s.89.

holdings.text: On construction of the will, the testator did not intend Seetharama to have the right of selection nor that daughters get lands accounting for good and bad quality; words 'he shall give' mean deliver possession as guardian.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is clear that there are no express words in the will which show that Seetharama shall select the land to be handed over to the two daughters. Can it be said merely because in one case the words used are he shall give to the female children and in the other case the words are he shall deliver possession to my son that by the use of the former words the testator was giving the right of selection to Seetharama ? As we read the will it seems to us that though the words are different in the case of daughters as compared to the words used in the case of the foster son, the meaning of the testator is the same, namely, that Seetharama who was the guardian of the three children will be in possession so long as the three children were minor and shall deliver possession of the properties to the children as and when they became major.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis: no express nomination of Seetharama as selector; 'give' and 'deliver possession' synonymous in guardianship context; no words for quality adjustment or share vs specific area.

holdings.text: The case squarely comes in the third class of cases where the testator neither indicated selection nor nominated third person, so daughters have right to select.

anchor.surface_text: The case, therefore, squarely comes in the third class of cases mentioned above by us, i.e., the testator had indicated with sufficient clarity what he wanted his daughters to get. The difficulty has arisen because vattam No. 149 has 21.38 acres of nanja land and 16.99 acres of punja land while each daughter is given 6.66 acres each of nanja and punja lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification under three possibilities: falls in third where benevolent rule mandates legatee selection; specific quantity/type from identified vattam.

holdings.text: The gift cannot be said to be void for uncertainty within the meaning of s. 89, for it can be made certain by the selection of the daughters; testator intended each daughter to select the land devised out of the vattam.

anchor.surface_text: void for uncertainty within the meaning of s. 89, for it can be made certain by the selection of the daughters and is not so uncertain that it is impossible to make it certain. The vattam is indicated from which the land is to come, the area of nanja and punja lands to be taken by each daughter is fixed. But the area of two kinds of land in the vattam is more than that given to the daughters it must in the circumstances be held that the testator intended that each daughter will select the land devised out of the vattam.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention clear (quantity, type, location); excess land resolvable by selection; not total indefiniteness under s.89.

holdings.text: The further English rule that the legatee's heir cannot make the selection if legatee dies without electing is based on common sense.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the further English rule that the legatees heir cannot make the selection is also based on common sense, for the testator never had the legatees heirs in his mind when he made the bequest his intention could only be in a case where selection was necessary that the legatee should make the selection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Testator contemplates legatee, not heirs; distinguished Bharadwaja as unnecessary there.

precedents.cited_holding: if it were such or so much of my best linen as they should choose, or as my executors should choose for them, this would be good

anchor.surface_text: In Tapley v. Eagleton  3   1979  12 Chz D 683 , the testator devised two houses in King Street to the legatee.

precedents.cited_proposition: legatee entitled to elect which two houses out of three matching the description
precedents.cited_holding: the words meant two of my houses in King Street and that two of the houses out of three passed to the legatee who was entitled to elect which two he would take

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in this case was placed on an earlier case Duckmanton v. Duckmanton  1   1860  5 N. 219 157 E.R. 1165

anchor.surface_text: The same view was taken in Knapton v. Hindle 2 , which was a more difficult case inasmuch as the devise was of one house each to the nephews and nieces of the testatrix without names being mentioned, The companyrt however held following the analogy of Roman law that under the will there was a choice to the nephews and nieces  1941 ch. 428.

precedents.cited_proposition: beneficiaries entitled to choice or by lot if disagreement when no specific allocation
precedents.cited_holding: under the will there was a choice to the nephews and nieces and that in case of disagreement among them, the choice was to be determined by lots

anchor.surface_text: The matter has companye up for companysideration in two cases in the Madras High Court. In the first case, Narayanaswami Gramani Periathambi Granmni  1   1895  I.L.R. 18 Mad. 460 , the testator owned land measuring one kani and three quarters.

precedents.cited_proposition: devisee entitled to select specific portion of land when will bequeaths part of larger holding
precedents.cited_holding: In a case like the present the devisee has clearly the right to choose. It has been lon settled that if a man devises two acres out of four acres that lie together, this is a good devise and the devisee shall select

precedents.citation: Bharadwaja Mudaliar v. Kolandavelu Mudaliar  2   1915  29 M.L.J. 717

anchor.surface_text: The matter came up again in Bharadwaja Mudaliar v. Kolandavelu Mudaliar  2   1915  29 M.L.J. 717 . In that case the will gave to the legatee six acres of good irrigated nanja lands in the village of Pudur .

precedents.cited_proposition: heir of legatee not entitled to make selection if legatee died without selecting; partition instead
precedents.cited_holding: the bequest was number void for uncertainty and that the heir would be entitled to six acres on partition but was number entitled to selection

anchor.surface_text: He therefore distinguished the earlier case of Narayanasami Gramani  1   1895 I.L.R. 18 Mad. 460 on that ground

precedents.cited_proposition: distinguished on ground that legatee died without selection

anchor.surface_text: the decision in Narayanasami Gramanis case  1   1895 I.L.R. 18 Mad. 460 is companyrect.

precedents.cited_proposition: decision correct that legatee entitled to select

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection we may refer to two other cases to which the learned Attorney-General drew our attention. The first is Asten v. Asten  1   1894 3 Ch. D. 260 .

precedents.cited_proposition: bequest void for uncertainty where identical descriptions apply to multiple properties for different legatees
precedents.cited_holding: the will was void for uncertainty, for there was numberway by which the will companyld be made certain

anchor.surface_text: The second case is Bishop v. Holt  2   1900 2 Ch. D. 620 . In that case the testatrix by her will gave her 140 shares in the Crown Brewery Company to the legatee for her life with remainder in trust for her children.

precedents.cited_proposition: specific shares taken from partly paid-up shares based on testator's intention inferable from holdings
precedents.cited_holding: they were to companye out of the 240 partly paid-up shares on the ground that the testatrixs intention was clear

justification_sets.label: Right of Selection by Legatee support

anchor.surface_text: The case, therefore squarely companes in the third class of cases mentioned above by us, i.e., the testator had indicated with sufficient clarity what he wanted his daughters to get. The difficulty has arisen because vattam No. 149 has 21.38 acres of nanja land and 16.99 acres of punja land while each daughter is given 6.66 acres each of nanja and punja lands. The gift cannot be said to be void for uncertainty within the meaning of s. 89, for it can be made certain by the selection of the daughters and is number so uncertain that it is impossible to make it certain. The vattam is indicated from which the land is to companye, the area of nanja and punja lands to be taken by each daughter is fixed. But the area of two kinds of land in the vattam is more than that given to the daughters it must in the circumstances be held that the testator intended that each daughter will select the land devised out of the vattam.

outcome.relief_summary: Daughters entitled to select one veli each of nanja and punja land from vattam No. 149; appellant's contentions rejected

anchor.surface_text: Now the provision of s. 89 applies only to those cases where a will is so indefinite that it is not possible to give any definite intention to it at all. The illustration to that section shows that it applies only where it is impossible to ascertain the intention of the testator from the words used in the will.

The case, therefore squarely companes in the third class of cases mentioned above by us, i.e., the testator had indicated with sufficient clarity what he wanted his daughters to get. The difficulty has arisen because vattam No. 149 has 21.38 acres of nanja land and 16.99 acres of punja land while each daughter is given 6.66 acres each of nanja and punja lands. The gift cannot be said to be void for uncertainty within the meaning of s. 89, for it can be made certain by the selection of the daughters and is number so uncertain that it is impossible to make it certain. The vattam is indicated from which the land is to companye, the area of nanja and punja lands to be taken by each daughter is fixed. But the area of two kinds of land in the vattam is more than that given to the daughters it must in the circumstances be held that the testator intended that each daughter will select the land devised out of the vattam.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us therefore that where it is not possible to say on the construction of a will that the testator himself indicated the selection or appointed a third person to make the selection but still intended to make a gift which could be made certain by selection made by the legatee, the English rule of construction that in such cases the testator intended the legatee to select should be applied in India also and the decision in Narayanasami Gramanis case 1 is correct.

The case, therefore squarely companes in the third class of cases mentioned above by us, i.e., the testator had indicated with sufficient clarity what he wanted his daughters to get. The difficulty has arisen because vattam No. 149 has 21.38 acres of nanja land and 16.99 acres of punja land while each daughter is given 6.66 acres each of nanja and punja lands. The gift cannot be said to be void for uncertainty within the meaning of s. 89, for it can be made certain by the selection of the daughters and is number so uncertain that it is impossible to make it certain. The vattam is indicated from which the land is to companye, the area of nanja and punja lands to be taken by each daughter is fixed. But the area of two kinds of land in the vattam is more than that given to the daughters it must in the circumstances be held that the testator intended that each daughter will select the land devised out of the vattam.
tances it was held that the will was void for uncertainty, for there was numberway by which the will companyld be made certain. The intention of the t

anchor.surface_text: Now it is clear that there are no express words in the will which show that Seetharama shall select the land to be handed over to the two daughters. Can it be said merely because in one case the words used are he shall give to the female children and in the other case the words are he shall deliver possession to my son that by the use of the former words the testator was giving the right of selection to Seetharama ? As we read the will it seems to us that though the words are different in the case of daughters as compared to the words used in the case of the foster son, the meaning of the testator is the same, namely, that Seetharama who was the guardian of the three children will be in possession so long as the three children were minor and shall deliver possession of the properties to the children as and when they became major.
ase and do number detract from the rule of benevolent companystruction in cases where the testator has number made or intended to make the selection h

anchor.surface_text: The case, therefore squarely companes in the third class of cases mentioned above by us, i.e., the testator had indicated with sufficient clarity what he wanted his daughters to get. The difficulty has arisen because vattam No. 149 has 21.38 acres of nanja land and 16.99 acres of punja land while each daughter is given 6.66 acres each of nanja and punja lands. The gift cannot be said to be void for uncertainty within the meaning of s. 89, for it can be made certain by the selection of the daughters and is number so uncertain that it is impossible to make it certain. The vattam is indicated from which the land is to companye, the area of nanja and punja lands to be taken by each daughter is fixed. But the area of two kinds of land in the vattam is more than that given to the daughters it must in the circumstances be held that the testator intended that each daughter will select the land devised out of the vattam.

The case, therefore squarely companes in the third class of cases mentioned above by us, i.e., the testator had indicated with sufficient clarity what he wanted his daughters to get.
